Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Quantum Physics and the Future

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the supervision of Susan Harding, Ph.D. student Christopher Cochran will adopt an ethnographic approach to study of the normative aspects of physics practice that shape subjectivity and the authority of the discipline. He will also document the ways that other scientists are collaborating with or using the work of quantum physicists, e.g. psychiatrists who collaborate with theoretical physicists to apply mathematical techniques of quantum field theory to neuronal networks, and analytic philosophers who hope that paradoxes of the mind-body problem can be fixed with concepts from quantum physics. The co-PI will investigate how concerns about the future are implicated in attempts to invent new ways of articulating scientific questions and new methods to obtain answers and may result in the creation of a new social/scientific formation.

The research promises to promote scientific literacy about quantum physics by encouraging understanding of the difference between empiricism and speculation. After completing the dissertation the co-PI plans on publishing his results as a book aimed at a wide public audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI has investigated the emerging science of quantum consciousness in its scientific, philosophical and "spiritual" aspects. The PI's dissertation analyzes the modern secular divide between religion and science through a study of quantum consciousness scientists who argue the whole universe is a conscious entity. Quantum consciousness (QC) scientists challenge the modern boundary between science and religion by creating spiritual knowledge based in quantum physics rather than holy books. His study suggests anxiety about present and future crisis, including climate change, motivates QC researchers to break with secularizing disciplinary boundaries. HIs ethnography explores QC research meetings, conferences, classrooms, textual life, and QC’s “fans” and followers to demonstrate the imbrication of QC in scientific, spiritual and religious communities. He argue the capacity of quantum physics to generate spiritual concepts shows contemporary science is a site of struggle over the legitimacy of boundary making practices that separate or entangle science and religion. QC gives perspective on larger trends that politicize science, including religious movements, the New Age, militant atheism, and post-modernism. QC scientists, like others above, experience the authority of the scientific worldview to be waning. Rather than dismiss or retrench scientific authority, QC scientists hope to resurrect it with a spiritual reformism that addresses anxieties about the future.
